reviewText: I will NOT be buying this set or changing my 1 star review until it is confirmed that Warner is including the two missing cartoons "Mouse Cleaning" and "Casanova Cat."I boycotted the T&J; spotlight collections because of the edits.  T&J; Golden Collection Vol.1 finally did not contain edits and for the first time ever T&J; fans could see light at the end of the tunnel.  But now with VOL.2 Warner has blown up the exit to that tunnel with censorship dynamite leaving the fans sad and crushed.Golden collection Volume 1 was amazing.  Please, Warner, do it again.

reviewText: I'd like to buy the two Blu-Ray volumes at once, but I've changed my mind. I've bought the Spotlight Collection 6 DVD, unedited version.  Anyway, I also had to buy the UK version to have the two missing cartoons, "Casanova Cat" and "Mouse Cleaning".  Both are included intact, but now I have a lot of DVDs of the same cartoons, and many other cartoons in this British version are butchered (Oscar winner "The Little Orphan" didn't show some blackface gags!).  So, I will never buy this Blu-Ray Volume Two, unless Warner correct it, as they did with the American DVDs.
summary: I will keep my Spotlight Tom & Jerry DVD collection

reviewText: Angry doesn't begin to express how I feel. We were promised that we'd finally get the long awaited "MOUSE CLEANING" and "CASSANOVA CAT" on DVD - and now the higher ups at Warners have swapped them out over fear of offending a few people.  Well, guess what? By removing them YOU HAVE OFFENDED A HELL OF A LOT MORE PEOPLE! I also understand that the planned release of the Looney Tunes Censored 11 has also now been shelved!  Please grow up Warner Brothers-grow a back bone and realize that not everyone will be offended by animated cartoons. They are as legitimate as any of the vintage movies that are out there.  Like many animation fans, I will avoid purchasing Warner products until you change your policy and release these cartoon shorts-the Tom & Jerrys & the Censored 11.

reviewText: So the "Tom and Jerry Golden Collection Volume 2" will be missing "Mouse Cleaning" and "Casanova Cat." Tom and Jerry fans have waited a long time for the original, uncut cartoons. The "Golden Collection Volume 1" was a dream come true after the utter mess Warner Bros. made of the Spotlight Collection. It's confusing that the first volume of the "Golden Collection" managed to be released uncut and now Warner Bros. is censoring Volume 2. It's a slap in the face to those of us who really love these cartoons and understand the context in which they were made. I (and I am sure many others) will not be buying this set or any other Tom and Jerry releases as long as Warner Bros. treats Tom and Jerry (and their fans) with this utter disrespect.

reviewText: Warner Brothers set out to make the Golden Collection the definitive assembly of Tom & Jerry cartoons. But after the excellent effort with the first volume, this second one is being released with two cartoons missing. The two titles are  "Mouse Cleaning" and "Casanova Cat", upon which all the restoration work was already complete and the notes for the DVD set written.It seems Warner got cold feet due to some politically incorrect humour that is present from the time that these cartoons were made. Context is everything - any sensible person knows the times have changed and understands that some of those jokes and references would not be said nowadays. So there is no reason at all not to preserve and present these amazing cartoons restored and uncut as they were meant to be. I and many other animation fans will not touch this set while it remains incomplete.
summary: Golden Collection vol 2 is MISSING TWO CARTOONS - it is not uncut as Warners said it would be!

I thought with these Golden Collection releases they would make it right, but the WB's day of grace has passed as far as Tom and Jerry is concerned. I'm not spending anything more on them.

reviewText: Two cartoons ("Mouse Cleaning" and "Casanova Cat") have been removed from the chronological sequence of cartoons in this set.  For a collection that was widely expected to be a definitive collection of all classic T&J; cartoons in multiple volumes, this is a severe misstep for the entire project and damages much confidence in my willingness to invest in this series.The T&J; Golden Collection Vol. 1, encompassing the first 37 T&J; cartoons produced in 1940-1948, garnered praise for including new HD transfers and restoration work as the first step in a new T&J; home video effort to release all the Tom & Jerry cartoons in chronological order. Unlike previous efforts, this was aimed primarily for the adult collector which was clearly labelled on the outer case.  The previous "Spotlight Collection" DVD set was a decent effort, but most of the cartoons had no restoration work, used TV prints at least a decade old, and had censorship and authoring "mistakes" that involved cumbersome replacement disc ordering and replacing.  Of course, the same two cartoons were missing in the "Spotlight Collection" with no official explanation or even acknowledgement from Warner Home Video.Many Hollywood cartoons from the 1930s to 1950s weren't the wholesome, family-friendly entertainment that television and modern franchise holders have worked hard to sanitize them into being.  Specific racially-themed gags are those that the average viewer gets the least exposure to, because they are very much a part of their time and are seen today as negative and offensive stereotypes.  These sorts of scenes were the first to undergo widespread censure in the U.S. on television, that TV exposure the primary reason for their enduring popularity.Previous Warner Home Video releases in the past have used disclaimers to warn and educate viewers that some of the content is not suitable for children, could offend the viewer, and of the importance to preserve the entirety of the short to honestly showcase the era in which the cartoons were made--that unsavory racial caricatures and jokes towards certain races and ethnicities were the norm of that era in cinema and should be viewed today in that context instead of falsely acting like that sort of humor never existed.  Previous Warner Home Video releases have stayed true to this disclaimer in providing unedited cartoons in their Looney Tunes sets and truly chronological releases of the Popeye cartoons, including the rarely seen wartime cartoons featuring unflattering and mocking portrayals of the Imperial Japanese.However, by withholding these shorts from the Tom & Jerry Golden Collection Vol. 2, Warner Home Video is taking part in the hypocrisy and deceit that negative racial depictions did not exist in the Tom & Jerry theatrical cartoons and that it is better to pretend in never happened.  It doesn't matter to them that the offending gags themselves comprise a mere 5-10 seconds of the entire cartoon runtime of each.  It doesn't matter to them that both of these cartoons have fans who enjoy them anyway.  It doesn't matter to them that Warner Home Video doesn't represent the every potential customer in the ethnic community affected nor have they received any known backlash for similar sequences in Volume 1.  Instead, the handful of employees making this decision at WHV don't trust the consumer to have a mind of his or her own and have taken it upon themselves to decide for the consumer what cartoon they are allowed to watch let alone own.  The primary consumer the company claims is the "adult collector."
summary: Tom & Jerry Golden Collection #2 -- Whitewashed Edition

Title: N/A

reviewText: I was eagerly anticipating this blu ray set.  To me Tom and Jerry represent the pinnacle of cartoon animation.  Unfortunately this set will not include two of the greatest cartoons, "Mouse Cleaning" and "Casanova Cat".  Warner Brothers believes those cartoons are unsuitable for today's audience.  This is particularly unfortunate for "Mouse Cleaning" since that cartoon was restored from the original nitrate elements and would look amazing on blu ray.We are adults and understand that racial stereotypes, as wrong as they are, are an unfortunate part of our history.  To pretend they never existed is equally wrong.  Many of us believe these cartoons are more than entertainment - but are instead an original American art form, and as such the artistic integrity of these shorts should remain intact without being censored.  Customers were misled to believe the entire collection of 114 classic Tom and Jerry shorts would be released in chronological order complete and uncensored.  By failing to live up to these expectations Warner Brothers has antagonized their fan base.If Warner Brothers reverses their decision I will happily change this to a 5 star rating, as I'm sure most others will.

reviewText: While this set will indeed contain uncut prints of all cartoons included, we are once again being robbed of two of these cartoons, "MOUSE CLEANING", the title that should have opened this set, and "CASSANOVA CAT".  The reason for this glaring omission is the same as the issue surrounding all the T&J; cartoons that had been edited in the past--gags that involve stereotyping.  If this were a series meant for the average buyer, I'd totally understand this decision regarding insensitivity, but these sets are meant for the cartoon collector who would understand that such material is of its time and not meant as malicious in any way.  This is the one time that all the TOM & JERRY cartoons created theatrically for MGM will be included for posterity, and these two cartoons should be among those.  I am, therefore, imploring Warner Brothers to please make sure that these cartoons are in their proper chronological order and are placed in again as part of the series.  The gags included therein are no more dangerous than those already seen as part of the series.  These are considered the Holy Grail to collectors who like the classic theatrical MGM cartoon, and they understand that these kinds of gags are of their time.Please reconsider and make sure that these two titles, "MOUSE CLEANING" and "CASSANOVA CAT" are returned to the TOM & JERRY GOLDEN COLLECTION, VOL. 2.  It will make a big, big difference!

reviewText: Leaving out two cartoons because of some feared audience offense over racial stereotypes is idiotic. Warner Brothers did the same thing in their release of Jonny Quest: deleting lines from an episode over concerns about racial epithets. Just precede the cartoon with a disclaimer, but do not edit, censor, or omit these important cultural touchstones out of some concern for political correctness.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love Tom and Jerry, and I love Blu-ray, so I was over the moon about Volume One and purchased it from Amazon on release day. But now it seems that Warner have cold feet over two controversial shorts ("Casanova Cat" and "Mouse Cleaning") that they were apparently to include in Volume Two. I held off on commenting until I read this response from WB Classic Animation hours ago:"Warner Bros. Home Entertainment carefully monitors all content it plans for release. While undertaking a review of "Tom and Jerry: The Golden Collection Volume 2," the company felt that certain content would be inappropriate for the intended audience and therefore excluded several shorts."So, this obviously means that these shorts were planned and then scrapped because of their content, and this even though these releases are "for the adult collector". This is another of these shady moves studios use when they want to bury catalogue content that is unflattering for them. It isn't as though people don't know about "Mouse Cleaning" or "Casanova Cat", and it isn't as though people the world over would not easily be able to see these cartoons as a product of their time, but still, Warner chooses to disgrace themselves by pretending instead that these cartoons never existed.I won't be buying Volume Two or any further WB Animation until the situation is rectified, and these two shorts are given their proper release.
summary: I won't be buying it until the "inappropriate" shorts are restored to the release

reviewText: I was hoping for the 2 cartoons "Mouse Cleaning" (1948) and "Casanova Cat" (1951) to be included on this release and now they've omitted those 2 from this release again! This set is aimed for collectors who want every single Tom & Jerry cartoon on DVD and/or Blu Ray, not for little kids who just want these shorts edited!! And I hope "His Mouse Friday" (1951) won't be edited again and if it is, I'm bashing Warner Bros. on this release! But I've only heard about this since February, and if they instead include them as from the vault bonus cartoons, I'll change my mind and give it a good rating. So get this right Warner Bros.!!! IS THIS YOUR IDEA SANDER SCHWARTZ?!?!?!Update 4/1/13 (not an April Fools joke): Warner Home Video has recently announced that they have postpone/delayed its June 11th release date. So hopefully they will make changes to the content and will include those 2 cartoons on this release (Warner Bros. did listen to our negative complaints about it, it was the big shots at Warner Home Video who made the decision because they don't want to loose money. But since this release is delayed, they will possibly change their mind and include those 2 shorts on this release and make a buck or two in the process). I'm already crossing my fingers on this and its new release date.
